在 2020 年总统大选前夕以及令人担忧的结局中，唐纳德·特朗普的支持者转向一种新颖的理论来增加他们的候选人留在白宫的机会。特朗普的支持者援引“独立州立法机构”的理论，试图阻止宾夕法尼亚州和其他地方的州法院做出的裁决，这些裁决使covid-19大流行期间的投票变得更加容易，例如延长邮寄选票的最后期限。选举日结束后，法律顾问利用这一想法制定了一项激进计划，用唐纳德·特朗普的“替代”候选人名单取代乔·拜登赢得的州的选举人。

6 月 27 日，在摩尔诉哈珀案中，最高法院对这些举措背后的理论泼了一盆冷水：州立法机构拥有近乎绝对的权力，不受州法院的制约，可以制定联邦选举的条款。作为期末法庭匆忙的一部分——几起重大案件仍有待在 6 月底之前裁决，包括大学招生中平权行动的命运以及拜登先生的学生债务减免计划——首席法官约翰·罗伯茨 (John Roberts)正义，为三位自由派大法官（科坦吉·布朗·杰克逊、埃琳娜·卡根和索尼娅·索托马约尔）和特朗普挑选的两位大法官（艾米·科尼·巴雷特和布雷特·卡瓦诺）撰写。克拉伦斯·托马斯法官撰写了一份异议书，塞缪尔·阿利托法官部分同意，尼尔·戈萨奇法官全部同意。

摩尔从北卡罗来纳州开始。 2021年，该州共和党主导的立法机构绘制了一张选举地图，共和党在该州众议院14个席位中占据了10个席位。鉴于该州共和党和民主党之间的分歧几乎相等，北卡罗来纳州最高法院认为这种激进的选区划分不符合北卡罗来纳州宪法中所有“选举应自由”的保证。它命令专家重新划定地区界限。 2022 年，使用更公平的地图，共和党和民主党各赢得了 7 个席位。但共和党议员犹豫不决，称联邦宪法本应阻止北卡罗来纳州最高法院干预。

他们的抱怨的文字线索出现在宪法第一条中，其中规定国会的“举行选举的时间、地点和方式”“应由各州的立法机关规定”。北卡罗来纳州共和党人认为，这意味着任何州实体都不得限制州立法机构履行选举监管的“联邦职能”。

首席大法官罗伯茨断然驳回了这一论点。他写道：“从我们国家历史的早期开始，法院就认识到他们有责任评估立法行为的合宪性。”他继续说，联邦宪法可能授权州立法机关制定管理选举的法律，但这“并不能使州立法机关免受州司法审查的正常行使”。首席大法官援引了最高法院一个多世纪前的判决，解释了立法机关在选举法方面从来都不是自主行为者。他写道，在 1932 年的一个案例中，“我们一致接受的推理值得我们继续尊重”。州立法者“不得‘设立独立于州宪法关于颁布法律’的要求的国会选区”。

就在八年前，最高法院裁定亚利桑那州选民有权将立法机关的选区重新划分任务外包给一个独立委员会。最终结果是 5 比 4，首席大法官罗伯茨发表了激烈的反对意见。但他在 2015 年的投票并没有阻止这位酋长依靠先例来确认立法机关“受到州宪法规定的约束”。

托马斯法官在他的异议中辩称，法院缺乏考虑摩尔的管辖权，因为北卡罗来纳州最高法院（在最近获得共和党多数席位后）已经推翻了对扭曲地图合宪性的裁决。他写道，此案“毫无争议”。但法庭上任职时间最长、最保守的法官也驳回了多数人关于案情的推理。法院对显着的宪法条款“没有提供明确的解释”。托马斯法官警告说：“我担心今天的意见预示着司法机构将面临严重的麻烦。”

一些左翼观察家认为托马斯大法官可能有道理。在拒绝州立法机构完全自治的同时，首席大法官罗伯茨的意见也否认州法院完全服从联邦法院。在没有制定标准的情况下，大多数人认为州法官不得“违宪地侵犯州立法机关专门保留的职责”。换句话说，州法院在监督州立法机构的选举活动时所能做的事情是有限的，而联邦法院将密切关注。

右翼法官托马斯担心，随之而来的不确定性将使联邦法官在“摆在他们面前的一些政治上最激烈、进展最快的案件”中缺乏指导。加州大学洛杉矶分校的选举法专家里克·哈森（Rick Hasen）（左翼）担心这“会导致最高法院权力的争夺”。但这些担忧可能被夸大了。去年冬天反对独立州立法机构理论的三名律师都承认，联邦法院可能需要偶尔介入，以纠正州法院判决中的严重错误。从摩尔案中对州法院作用的强烈肯定来看，六位大法官的多数派似乎并不想袖手旁观。继本月早些时候在选区重新划分中反对种族歧视后，最高法院再次站出来反对颠覆民主。 ■

; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 21:43:18 GMT /内容/bi2p10mleg604rrsoh32klcpg07jed0q https://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/06/27/the-supreme-court-declines-to-upend-american-election-law The choice between a poorer today and a hotter tomorrow

假设您是发展中国家的财政部长。当你的纳税额令人失望的一年结束时，你就快没钱了。你可以将所剩无几的资金投入到你的医疗保健系统中：诊所花费的美元有助于控制传染病，而且发展专家认为没有太多现金可以更好地利用。但你也可以花钱建设一个能够转向清洁能源的电网。从长远来看，这将意味着更少的污染、更多产的农田和更少的洪水。边际美元的使用哪个更明智：立即缓解严重贫困，还是为国家出一份力，阻止地球被烘烤？

这个思想实验是全球机构和发展中国家面临的困境的简化版本。 6 月 22 日，政界人士齐聚巴黎，召开峰会，设计“新的全球金融协议”。目的是找出如何分摊气候变化的成本。来自贫穷国家的领导人纷纷出席；除了法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙之外，没有西方国家元首上榜。因此，这次盛会结束时，富裕国家没有额外掏出一美元，也就不足为奇了。相反，与会者对世界银行和国际货币基金组织进行了修改，这两个机构是寻求减少贫困的最大多边机构。缺乏行动意味着未来将面临痛苦的权衡。

毕竟，帮助贫穷国家走向绿色需要大量资金。 2000年，除中国以外的发展中国家的年碳排放量不足30%。到2030年，他们将占大多数。伦敦经济学院智库格兰瑟姆研究所估计，此时贫穷国家每年需要花费 2.8 万亿美元来减少排放并保护其经济。该研究所认为，无论气候如何变化，这些国家每年还需要在医疗保健和教育等方面花费 3 万亿美元，以保持扶贫努力。这个数字可能还会上升。自covid-19来袭以来，从艾滋病毒死亡人数到绝对贫困人数等发展指标的进展都陷入停滞。

世界的支出远未达到这样的数额。 2019 年，即可获得可靠数据的最新一年，气候和发展方面的支出合计仅为 2.4 万亿美元。根据格兰瑟姆研究所的说法，富裕国家和开发银行必须承担至少 1 万美元的年度缺口（其余部分应直接来自私营部门和发展中国家本身）。 2009 年，富裕国家同意到 2020 年每年提供 1000 亿美元的新融资。此后，他们每年都未能实现这一目标，到 2020 年仅达到 830 亿美元，其中大部分资金来自开发银行。不包括气候融资和国内难民支出，过去十年来自经合组织国家的援助一直持平。

在最近的一篇文章中，包括美国的乔·拜登、肯尼亚的威廉·鲁托和阿拉伯联合酋长国的穆罕默德·本·扎耶德在内的世界领导人写道，他们相信“减少贫困和保护地球是共同的目标”。一些政策确实为两者提供了有用的解决方案。可持续农业可以减少排放、应对气候变化的粮食供应并降低饥荒的风险。红树林保护可以固碳、阻止风暴潮并帮助渔民谋生。总体而言，气候变化造成的损害使开发成本更高，而阻止气候变化则使开发成本变得更便宜。

但尽管对齐是可能的，但这种情况也很少见。减排支出将不可避免地针对中等收入国家，因为这些国家污染更严重；减贫支出将针对穷人居住的低收入地区。国际货币基金组织的研究人员分析了 1990 年以来 72 个发展中国家的数据，发现存在一种不幸的模式：平均每年GDP增长 1%，排放量就会增长 0.7%。

原因很简单。不断发展的工业需要大量电力。大型机械化农业需要大量空间；它的增长是森林砍伐的主要原因。非洲开发银行 ( af db ) 估计，到 2025 年，非洲需要 160 吉瓦 ( gw ) 的额外产能。非洲大陆目前仅生产 30吉瓦左右的可再生能源。最近在阿克拉举行的非洲进出口银行年会上，讨论的主题是如何开采金属以实现绿色转型，而很少担心这将涉及的污染。

从理论上讲，下一代工业化国家可以使用可再生电网而不是依靠石油和天然气的电网来为其增长提供动力。非洲拥有比世界上任何地方都多的太阳能潜力，以及大量可用于电池的矿物。然而，尽管绿色增长是可能的， 但它并没有发生——更换旧电网和安装新技术对于发展中国家来说太昂贵了。官方预测机构国际能源署估计，为了到 2050 年实现净零排放，发展中国家到 2030 年必须在可再生电网上花费至少 3000 亿美元，是其当前支出的五倍。

绿色梦想

因此，资金缺失是没有办法解决的。正如巴黎会议的微薄进展所表明的那样，援助支出不太可能大幅增加。会议结束后，捐助国和世界银行现在计划在发生极端天气灾难时暂停更多还款，并从富裕国家回收了少量特别提款权，这是国际货币基金组织分配到资产负债表上的金融工具每个国家的中央银行。一些承诺的资金将来自何处以及支出机制尚未透露。

非洲政治家提出了更雄心勃勃的提议，其中包括全球税收和新的国际金融机构的想法，正如鲁托先生所说，“不成为股东的人质”。他们被视为古怪的人。 “由谁征税？又是为了谁呢？”马克龙先生问道。即使是马克龙支持的全球范围内的航运税，也面临着多年的政治争论。 “几个月后我们就会忘记这一切，”一位财政部长叹息道。 “全球利益与国家利益之间存在冲突，”鲁托先生说。 “而国家利益总是获胜。”

这产生了两个惨淡的权衡。第一个问题涉及各国政府的优先事项。由于缺乏准备和酷热的气温，发展中国家是最容易受到气候变化影响的国家之一。在接下来的几十年里，污染和极端高温将使健康状况恶化。自然灾害会造成严重破坏并造成巨大的重建成本。但从短期来看，各国政府不确定如何在没有化石燃料的情况下实现增长。这些国家的经济因电网不稳定和能源不足而受到阻碍，这意味着官员们正在寻找电力。石油、天然气和其他原材料商品是出口国的宝贵外汇来源。根据国际货币基金组织的报告，如果没有化石燃料收入，包括厄瓜多尔和加纳在内的至少十几个贫穷国家将面临难以控制的债务负担。政府并不总是对化石燃料的补贴负责，但近年来污染物却为非洲社会支出和养老金缴款支付了数十亿美元。

为公共服务寻找资金的短期压力很大。去年，在向债权人和公务员付款后，赞比亚的预算只剩下 13%。该国是一个极端的例子，但大多数发展中国家的政府几乎没有回旋余地。 “我如何向选民证明取消补贴、学校经费和医疗保健以建造废物处理厂或大型海堤是合理的？”财政部长问道。 “当然，20 年后它就会有用，但现在令人担忧的是成本。”这位部长认为，由于需要使设施变得绿色和有弹性，在他的首都建造学校的成本在过去十年中增加了一倍。 “当我们必须在治疗肺部疾病的医院和换成电动公交车之间做出选择时，该怎么办？”

结果是，发展中国家距 2015 年第 21 届缔约方会议首次提出的国家气候目标还有很长的路要走。至少到 2030 年，新建燃煤电厂将为印度尼西亚提供 60% 的电力。相关的碳排放将推动该国距最近向缔约方会议提交的排放目标还很远。 2019 年至 2027 年间，巴西政策制定者计划在石油和天然气方面投入 5000 亿美元，以避免因日益频繁的干旱而导致水电短缺。 “非洲国家需要一个公平的化石燃料退出计划，”智库非洲经济事务中心的马维斯·奥乌苏-贾姆菲 (Mavis Owusu-Gyamfi) 说。

马太效应

这让国际金融家面临下一个权衡。如果目标是尽快减少排放，或“缓解”气候变化，那么最好的支出方式就是向中等收入大国提供廉价贷款和赠款。去年，印度尼西亚的燃煤能源工业排放的二氧化碳比撒哈拉以南非洲地区减去南非后还要多。该国的燃煤电厂将在 2050 年之前实现盈利，除非政府通过廉价贷款和赠款说服它们提前退役。根据国际货币基金组织的研究人员的说法，到 2030 年为止，每年需要向三大中等收入国家（印度、印度尼西亚和南非）提供约 3,570 亿美元的资金，以便在 2050 年之前逐步淘汰这些国家的燃煤电厂。巴巴多斯部长是马克龙巴黎会议的共同主办者，他正在推动世界银行向中等收入国家提供通常为最贫困人口保留的廉价利率。

美元在中等收入国家走得更远，因为更容易吸引私人资金。在巴黎，世界银行新任行长阿贾伊·班加(Ajay Banga)领导的一个小组对需要优惠融资的担保和保险计划充满了想法。大多数人将登陆中等收入国家，那里有大型私营部门，而且做生意非常简单。这些国家也更渴望清洁能源，因为清洁能源会带来回报，而不是为了抵御气候变化的影响而采取昂贵的适应措施，因为后者不会带来现金。 “每个月都有石油和天然气[公司]来敲我的门。你知道[私营部门]为了保护我的森林付出了多少努力吗？没有，”一位非洲部长说。去年，肯尼亚和富裕国家为非洲举办了一场人道主义筹款活动。发达经济体只承诺了 24 亿美元，而目标是 70 亿美元。

迄今为止最大的气候融资项目是jet - ps （即“正义能源转型”一揽子计划），由银行、富裕国家和私营企业提供的贷款和赠款组成，旨在引导中等收入国家从化石燃料转向使用化石燃料。更清洁的能源。印度尼西亚的一揽子计划价值 200 亿美元，其中约 100 亿美元来自其他政府以低廉的价格提供。南非已经赢得了 85 亿美元的优惠融资，尽管该国总统西里尔·拉马福萨毫不奇怪地认为该国应该获得更多。此类计划物有所值。如果印度尼西亚坚持其jet - p承诺，而不是其国家能源计划，它将在2030年将年发电量排放量限制在290兆吨。这将涉及关闭多个燃煤电厂，并成为世界上少数几个排放量接近290兆吨的国家之一。世界升温仅 1.5°C 所需的那些。

赠款是发展金融的金粉。由于可用资金有限，人们担心依赖廉价融资的低收入国家将错失良机。这些国家的部长们担心能源转型缺乏资金。如果没有支持，他们将因投资化石燃料设施而留下搁浅资产，而对化石燃料设施的需求很少。但他们更担心必须削减健康和教育方面的支出。最终，他们可能别无选择。 2021 年，发展机构向最贫困国家提供的赠款和廉价贷款不到四分之一，低于十年前的近三分之一。 2021 年，包括尼日利亚和巴基斯坦在内的 80 个贫穷国家总共只收到了 220 亿美元的缓解和适应援助。去年，对撒哈拉以南非洲地区的双边援助下降了 8%。

在巴黎，肯尼亚和乍得总统举行了活动，批评富裕国家在债务减免方面的瘫痪。 “我们希望得到一点理解，”鲁托先生抱怨道。毫不奇怪的是，他们并不支持莫特利女士向中等收入国家提供更慷慨贷款的运动。私下里，他们还抱怨西方的虚伪。欧洲领导人要求贫穷国家停止补贴化石燃料，并完全放弃发展天然气和煤炭作为国内能源，同时让国内燃煤电厂投入运行，并增加从非洲的天然气进口。

世界最大的气候和发展融资提供者世界银行陷入了这两个目标之间。作为美国财政部长，珍妮特·耶伦对该机构拥有巨大的影响力，去年她在非洲之行的大部分时间都在哀叹其气候融资的质量。智库全球发展中心发现，该行自 2000 年以来设立的 2,500 个气候融资项目几乎没有对排放量或各国为更炎热的世界做好准备的程度产生明显影响。尽管这些项目宣称有绿色意图，但大部分支出都用于服务于世行扶贫目标的工作。

事实上，世行在气候变化问题上遇到麻烦的部分原因是它的目标是扶贫。它正计划建立一个新系统来跟踪其支出对气候变化的影响。然而，对于如何进一步推进，还有一些建议。这些措施包括为气候变化提供额外贷款（该贷款已占贷款总额的三分之一以上），以及改变银行家获得奖金的标准，从他们发放的贷款金额到私营部门融资的金额这些提议加剧了低收入国家的担忧，即修复世界银行可能会减少扶贫资金的流动。

财务困难

在巴黎的幕后，断层线已经凝固。一些国际金融界人士认为，气候问题现在是当务之急。他们认为，如果没有可供人类居住的星球，那么扶贫就没有意义了。 “我们已经讨论发展问题 40 年了，”格兰瑟姆研究所的 Vera Songwe 说道。 “这是我们在气候方面所没有的奢侈。”希望一些国家能够从绿色转型中致富。该阵营认为，无论如何，所有国家都需要消除净排放，包括非洲国家，其中一些国家几乎没有排放。大量资金应该转移到目前排放最多的国家。应做出妥协以吸引私人资本参与。多边开发银行需要新的标准来判断其贷款，而政府则需要帮助有效地支出其气候融资。

其他人不同意。 “请不要让[气候融资]以牺牲人力资本的基本投资为代价，”慈善机构盖茨基金会首席执行官马克·苏兹曼(Mark Suzman)表示。该组织认为，只有在技术工人的健康和教育方面的进步所带来的生产率提高奠定基础的情况下，绿色转型才会奏效。该组织的成员想知道中等收入国家是否需要像他们声称的那样多的帮助。他们认为，最贫穷的国家应该获得用于适应的气候融资，而不是附带排放限制的东西。

什么算适应融资是这场争论的早期热点。发展营统计了增强“气候适应能力”的支出，其中包括学校配备雨水渠，以及向孩子们传授绿色科技等方面的支出。气候阵营将其中一些称为“绿色清洗”。国际金融家之间正在进行这场辩论，而不是让发展中国家在如何使用这些资金方面拥有主要发言权，这种想法让当地部长们感到愤怒。甚至规模较小的机构也在选边站。由中国牵头的亚洲投资和基础设施银行正在考虑将其所有贷款转向气候融资。与世界银行不同，它不致力于扶贫。 “它（扶贫）将成为第二要务，”一位官员耸耸肩。

在报道这篇文章时，本报记者采访了参与这场辩论的 20 多位经济学家、金融家和政策制定者。当被问及气候还是发展应该是最终优先事项时，他们的忠诚度各不相同。随着世界变得越来越热，贫困问题也同样紧迫，分裂只会扩大。 ■

如果孩子要画一座灯塔，他们就会画特莱沃斯。这十分完美。上面是圆形的白墙；下面的岩石悬崖；远处波涛汹涌的大海。最重要的是它的光束。当太阳落山时，光束开始：暗-光-暗-光，整个夜晚，每个夜晚。 110 年来，特雷沃斯缓慢转动的光束席卷了天空、海洋和陆地。现在它要出去了。 10 月 23 日，特雷沃斯的扫射光束将停止。更简单的LED灯将取而代之。它会持续不断。但移动的光束将会消失。

英国的灯塔正在失去其影响力。一个多世纪以来，许多在英国海洋和海岸上空翱翔的巨梁，几乎更多的是隐喻，而不仅仅是海上援助，正在被逐步淘汰。他们巨大的、缓慢转动的镜片被一一移除；取而代之的是一一较简单的闪烁LED会闪烁。许多人会留下来（因为它们太棘手而难以更换）；但很多人已经走了。比奇角 (Beachy Head) 和波特兰比尔 (Portland Bill) 的灯光已经消失；萨克岛也是如此。弗兰伯勒也是如此。

令人惊讶的是，许多这样的灯塔竟然存在。建造 50 米高的塔楼很困难；剑桥大学建筑与建筑史教授詹姆斯·坎贝尔表示，在波涛汹涌的大海中在崎岖的岩石上建造它们是“你能做的最危险的事情”。早期的灯塔有的倒塌，有的被烧毁，有的像风暴中的沙堡一样被冲走。 1756 年，一位名叫约翰·斯米顿 (John Smeaton) 的英国皇家学会工程师决定采取不同的做法：他没有将自己的 Foursquare 建在海边，而是仿制英国橡树的树干，这种树干能够很好地抵御风暴。一种新风格的灯塔——高大、锥形、弯曲——开始在英国海岸周围生长；如今，英格兰和威尔士有 66 艘在使用，其中许多都很细长，像树木一样在强风中摇摆。

它们只是众多灯中的一些。旱鸭子几乎永远不会注意到海岸线上有成千上万的灯光：有些是红色的，有些是绿色的，有些是白色的；有的闪烁，有的转动，有的静止；沿海圣诞节展示，告诉水手该去哪里。它们可能很漂亮，但它们的位置很精确，因为它们充当水手的三角绊线：朝这边航行太远，这些灯就不会对齐；朝那个方向转向太远，灯就会变成红色。

在它们之上是灯塔——尽管它们的宏伟几乎是一种视错觉：特莱沃斯的巨大光束来自一个你可以握在手掌上的 35 瓦小灯泡。从各个方面来说，它们的辉煌都在于菲涅尔透镜，灯塔巨大的、缓慢转动的玻璃透镜（想象一下它们的形状，想象一颗鹅卵石掉进池子里，然后它的涟漪冻结了），它不断地反射光线，直到它变成了一根向大海传播30公里的光束。每个透镜都很大——比人高，超过三吨——但在水银床上保持着如此微妙的平衡，你可以用一根手指推动它——一头冰上的大象——转动它。

那些汞就是他们必须离开的原因。 Trinity House 负责管理英格兰和威尔士的灯塔，目前正在努力清除其资产中的所有汞含量；部分原因是它有毒，部分原因是转向灯更容易出错。无论如何，灯塔并不是真的为了扫荡； “织布机”只是提供定时闪光，让水手知道他们正在看哪盏灯。每个灯塔都是海上莫尔斯电码，都有自己的模式：比奇角每二十秒闪烁两次；特雷沃斯每七点半一次。 LED可以轻松做到这一点。拿掉织布机，你就拿走了诗歌——但三位一体之家导航要求负责人奈杰尔·黑尔表示，这也是它们失败的“很大一部分风险”。

您还可以削减成本。 1996 年，经济学家威廉·诺德豪斯 (William Nordhaus) 写了一篇论文，比较了自巴比伦时代以来照明成本的下降情况，并找到了答案：大量下降。今天一小时的工作所购买的光线是古代巴比伦的 350,000 倍。 Trinity House是诺德豪斯对航海形式的洞察：40年前，他们有1,900名员工，其中每个灯塔都有三名灯塔看守人；船夫为他们带来食物和燃料，推笔者则负责管理他们。如今，他们已经拥有 300 座灯塔。所有英国灯塔都是无人值守的：打开一扇灯塔的门，迎接您的是寂静和发动机油的气味。

现在，在特雷沃斯，照亮海洋所需的能量将再次下降。几个月后，伟大的光束仍将在海浪中搜索，但透镜即将出现；到11月它就会消失。光束将最后一圈——天空、海洋、陆地——然后它和一个时代就会结束。 ■

国际货币基金组织喜欢说它永远不会离开谈判桌。如果一个国家需要救助，则没有最后期限：只要需要，谈判就可以继续进行。一些国家似乎决心检验这一承诺。

埃及、黎巴嫩和突尼斯都急需帮助。它们居住着阿拉伯世界约三分之一的人口，背负着高额债务和不断减少的外汇储备。他们正在努力进口基本必需品并支撑疲软的货币。

黎巴嫩已于 2020 年出现债务违约；其他两个国家的债券因其垃圾评级而支付高收益率。国际货币基金组织中东地区主任吉哈德·阿祖尔（Jihad Azour）表示：“最脆弱的经济体正被推向债务困境的边缘。”（他在祖国黎巴嫩被提名为总统候选人后于 6 月暂时休假）。

这三个国家都向国际货币基金组织寻求贷款，希望增强其金融缓冲并安抚外国投资者。然而，在与该基金进行多年谈判后，这三者都陷入了停滞。这些延误在很大程度上说明了阿拉伯世界石油进口国的经济失调，也说明了国际货币基金组织在该地区的项目存在问题。

首先是埃及，该国去年 12 月与国际货币基金组织达成了 30 亿美元的协议。自 2019 年以来，其外汇储备已从 440 亿美元下降至 350 亿美元，而公共债务占GDP的比例从 80% 上升至预计今年的 93%。投资者因俄罗斯入侵乌克兰而感到恐慌，去年将 220 亿美元的证券投资撤出该国。由于美元稀缺，自 2022 年初以来，埃及已使英镑贬值 3 次，将英镑兑美元汇率减半至 30 左右。

阿卜杜勒-法塔赫·塞西政府希望国际货币基金组织的协议能够恢复信心。它承诺转向灵活汇率并出售数十亿美元的国有资产。不过，英镑看起来仍然被高估，黑市交易价格在 30 多美元左右。 5月份年度通胀率达到33%，接近历史新高，远远超过央行18.25%的利率。

政府坚称，在英镑贬值或再次加息之前，必须建立硬通货缓冲。可以理解的是，外国投资者希望这种情况发生逆转：负实际利率和过于强势的货币使得埃及的债务及其国有资产看起来都是糟糕的赌注。结果，其经济和国际货币基金组织的计划陷入了僵局。 The first review of its progress under the agreement, which would unlock further tranches of aid, was meant to be completed in March. It remains unfinished.

Tunisia, with government debt of more than 80% of its GDP , started talks with the fund early last year. Foreign reserves have fallen from $9.8bn in 2020 to $6.8bn today. There are frequent shortages of staple foods, such as rice and sugar; pharmacies no longer stock scores of medicines.

While it will probably muddle through 2023 without a default, it may struggle to repay close to $2.6bn in external debts next year. But Kais Saied, the country's authoritarian president, all but rejects the idea of an IMF deal, calling “foreign diktats” unacceptable (despite having agreed to start talks with the fund).

Then there is Lebanon, which reached a preliminary agreement with the fund last April. Since 2019 it has plunged into one of the worst economic crises in modern history, the result of a years-long central-bank Ponzi scheme to prop up the currency. Banks are insolvent. The lira has since lost 98% of its value. Annual inflation has been above 100% for almost three years.

To finalise the agreement, the IMF asked Lebanon to implement a few modest reforms: draft a plan to restructure the banks, overhaul the bank-secrecy law and unify its myriad exchange rates. The government has dawdled for more than a year.

Powerful elites are blocking progress in all three countries. Egypt's army does not want to sell off lucrative assets and allow civilian firms to compete. Trade unions in Tunisia, which periodically call strikes that bring the country to a halt, reject efforts to cut subsidies or trim the wage bill. Politicians and bankers who led Lebanon into crisis are loth to admit that the financial sector is zombified.

Yet Mr Sisi is not wrong to fret that another devaluation will hurt Egyptians, nor Mr Saied to worry about increased poverty. Egypt weakened the currency, cut subsidies and raised taxes after signing a $12bn deal with the IMF in 2016. That meant painful inflation and tighter budgets for citizens—without fixing the country's underlying problems. Mr Sisi had to come back for another imf loan before he finished repaying the last one.

Austerity only brings a small reprieve in countries that share deeper ills. One is a reliance on tourism and remittances, rather than exports, as the main source of hard currency. They spend hefty sums on enormous public-sector wage bills, which leaves little in the budget for social services or investment. Growth has been sluggish: Egypt's non-oil private sector has contracted for 30 consecutive months.

Fixing these problems requires a bigger strategy to boost growth. That seems unlikely with the current crop of leaders—and they seem unlikely to go anywhere.

Presidential elections in Egypt are scheduled for next February, but there is talk that Mr Sisi might bring them forward to late 2023. Some military officers and powerful businessmen are frustrated with his policies and might support a challenger. No one has announced plans to run, however, which is understandable under such a ruthless regime: before the last election, in 2018, several of his would-be opponents were arrested.

Mr Saied's five-year term is also due to end in 2024. He has spent the past few years hacking away at the foundations of Tunisia's young democracy, sacking parliament and drafting a new constitution to expand his powers. A fair election seems improbable. In Lebanon, meanwhile, sectarian politics mean that most voters continue to choose the same warlords and criminals who plunged the country into crisis. The country has not had a president since October and may soon lack a central-bank chief since Riad Salameh, the longtime governor, is due to leave office this summer.

For now, then, these countries are stuck. Tunisia has taken some loans from Algeria; Egypt has received a bit of help from its allies in the Gulf. European leaders, worried that economic crisis will drive migration, are also becoming more generous. Around 3,200 Tunisians crossed the Mediterranean to Italy in the first four months of this year, a 154% increase from the same period in 2022. Giorgia Meloni, the Italian prime minister, recently pledged €700m ($764m) in aid to Tunisia. Exasperated Italian officials have even wondered privately if the IMF might sign a deal with Tunisia without Mr Saied's approval. The answer, unsurprisingly, was no. ■

; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 17:42:35 GMT /content/69704qsil1ac0lca0tn1a5jdpcntri0q https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/06/27/after-years-of-talks-indebted-arab-states-and-the-imf-are-at-an-impasse What next for Wagner’s African empire?

U ntil the events of the past week it seemed that the Wagner Group's next outpost was more likely to be Burkina Faso than Belarus. But on June 27th Yevgeny Prigozhin arrived in the latter, as part of a deal that the country's president, Alexander Lukashenko, said he struck between the mutinous leader of the paramilitary network and Vladimir Putin. From there Mr Prigozhin will try to run the brutal African operations that have become crucial not just to his empire but to the Kremlin's approach to the continent.

Wagner has carried out “a huge number of tasks in the interests of the Russian Federation” in African and Arab countries, Mr Prigozhin complained in a Telegram message on June 26th. The mercenary group has sent fighters to five African states, including Mali and the Central African Republic ( CAR ), where operations by “instructors” will continue, insisted Sergey Lavrov, Russia's foreign minister, the same day. Wagner has also had some sort of presence in at least another seven countries on the continent (as well as Syria).

What happens now is unclear. But even if Mr Prigozhin, the group's figurehead, is sidelined it seems unlikely that Wagner will up sticks in Africa. The organisation is much more than just one man and it has a vested interest in staying put. Moreover the Kremlin will be loth to lose what has been a source of influence on the continent. Most probably, Wagner will retreat from Africa only if Africans themselves start to see Russia as a weak and unreliable partner.

To grasp what might happen next to Wagner's African empire it helps to understand how it operates. There is no Wagner Inc but a network of firms with links to the Russian state that operate under contracts with foreign governments. Like the colonial enterprises of the 19th century, these deals allow the Russian state to partake in adventures with less accountability than if it used regular troops.

When deployed in African countries, Wagner uses a business model that has three potential elements, the mix of each depending on the country it is in. These three elements—military, economic and political—have their clearest case study in the CAR , the former French colony that Wagner entered in 2018. Further evidence of its role there was provided on June 27th by the Sentry, an American investigative outfit, in a new report based on dozens of interviews and analysis of government documents and other sources.

The first pillar is the military one, in cases where African clients in search of security have turned to Russia and thus, Wagner. There are no official estimates of how many Wagner fighters are in Africa but analysts suggest the number is about 5,000, with most of these in Mali and the CAR . (It has unknown numbers still in Syria where it augmented Russian military efforts.) The total number may be relatively small, but interviews with Wagner defectors suggest that its Africa-based fighters are skilled and battle-hardened. They also enhance the capabilities of African states' own forces. In the CAR Wagner has raised a “parallel army” of roughly 5,000 fighters. Many of these are recruited from the same ethnic group as Faustin-Archange Touadéra, the president, outside the procedures monitored by the UN , according to the Sentry. It alleges that Wagner has trained the fighters in torture techniques and that it commands units outside Bangui, the capital. Wagner allegedly imported weapons, drones and aircraft in violation of a UN arms embargo.

Wagner used this parallel army as part of a “campaign of terror”, says the Sentry. It accuses Wagner of massacres, torture and rape as part of the group's strategy of “cleansing” villages. It quotes one CAR soldier under Wagner command as saying: “We kill villagers only, we bury them, or we throw them in the bush.” (Spokespeople for Mr Touadéra and the Wagner Group did not respond to requests for comment.)

Though The Economist could not independently verify the Sentry's claims, they chimed with other investigations, including by Human Rights Watch. The UN estimates that one in five people in the CAR is internally displaced or a refugee. An astonishing study published in April in Conflict and Health , a journal, suggests that 5.6% of the CAR ’s population died last year, more than four times the UN ’s estimate for the CAR in 2010 and more than twice the share reported by any other country. Wagner's presence “at least contributed to increased difficulties of survival”, say the researchers, diplomatically.

The second element of Wagner's business model is economic—the quid for a security quo. Wagner should not be thought of as a hierarchical business, but instead as a loose conglomerate with a network of subsidiaries. In January America added Wagner to its list of “transnational criminal organisations” that face sanctions. There is little transparency into its revenues or profitability, but what seems clear is that Africa is a crucial part of its money-making. In February, for instance, the EU imposed sanctions on a Wagner-linked firm for its role in the gold trade in Sudan.

In the CAR various nodes of Wagner's business network connect. Wagner, says the Sentry, has killed and looted villages near gold- and diamond-mining areas. Mining equipment from Russia is allegedly imported via Cameroon by a company registered in Madagascar. The Sentry counted 15 flights by Wagner-linked planes to Sudan, a gold-trafficking hub. It used satellite imagery to show the growth of Ndassima, a gold mine that was once the preserve of “artisanal” miners but is now allegedly run by a Wanger-linked firm. Wagner is also keen for it and the CAR ’s government to exert greater control over production by small-scale miners, alleges the Sentry.

The CAR is also a case study of the political services Wagner offers—the third element of its model. The Sentry notes that the group ran pro-Touadera campaigns in the run up to elections he won in 2020 and helped negotiate political deals with leaders of various factions. Elsewhere in Africa, Wagner companies have run propaganda and disinformation campaigns, and organised sham election-observation groups.

Understanding the Wagner model is useful in thinking through what may happen next. There is some speculation that as part of any deal between Mr Prigozhin and Mr Putin, the former may be able to maintain his role in Africa, though it is unclear if any such deal will be honoured. (On June 27th Russia's president seemed to emphasise who controlled whom when he admitted that the state had directly funded Wagner's operations, at least in Ukraine.) Some think that the profits Wagner earned in Africa may have provided an incentive for Mr Prigozhin to stage his uprising in Russia. “Wagner demanded more money and material to continue his actions in Africa,” a French diplomatic source familiar with the activities of the group told Le Monde , a newspaper. “That's where it all started.”

Given its structure, “whatever happens to Prigozhin says very little about what happens to the Wagner Group in Africa,” argues Kimberly Marten of Columbia University's Barnard College. He is neither the CEO of a unified Wagner firm nor a top-down commander. Though he may be a charismatic leader and adept at logistics, it would be “relatively easy” for Russia's defence establishment to replace him, she argues.

The people and entities in the Wagner network also have their own interests that they will wish to maintain. Some of these are linked to Mr Prigozhin; some much less so. The “bottom up” evolution of the group is often missed, argues John Lechner, the author of a forthcoming book on Wagner. “And even if there were a big shift at the top of management then you're not going to fire everyone else.”

Wagner has also been a critical part of the Kremlin's resurgent interest in Africa over the past decade. After the annexation of Crimea in 2014, and again last year, Russia redoubled its engagement on the continent. Next month Mr Putin will host African leaders at a summit in St Petersburg. Wagner is far from the only tool in its African toolkit, but it has been a low-cost high-impact instrument. “The advantages that Wagner offers the Russian state will still remain,” argues Julia Stanyard of the Global Initiative against Transnational Organised Crime, who co-authored a report into the group, published in February, that described Wagner's “tripartite” business model.

The advantages Wagner offers Russia are multiple. It is a source of gold, stockpiles of which help Russia resist the impact of Western financial sanctions. It also helps seed anti-Western messages across fertile ground in the African countries in which it operates. (Wagner was reportedly behind the lie that French soldiers were responsible for the killing of nine Chinese nationals at a mine in the CAR earlier this year.) It establishes unofficial channels of influence with African politicians that can be turned into official relationships. In the CAR , for instance, the country's ambassador to Russia recently suggested that things had gone so swimmingly with Wagner that his government would consider hosting a Russian military base.

Even so, the Russian security services may wish to alter the structure of its arrangements with Wagner. One option would be to nationalise the group, though that may suit neither the Russian state, which can currently claim to deny responsibility for Wagner's atrocities, nor African governments, who can more plausibly argue they remain in control of their security if they use mercenaries rather than foreign troops. Other options might be to rebrand the group, bring in new leadership or shift the constituent firms so that different elites are in control. Regardless, it would seem illogical for Russia to unilaterally withdraw from fruitful ventures. “It would damage Russia in the eyes of African governments if they pulled them out,” adds Ms Stanyard.

It may be that the most important factor in deciding Wagner's future on the continent will be its African customers—the politicians who have turned to Russia for help. In the CAR , where Wagner's influence is most entrenched, the government seems unmoved. Fidèle Gouandjika, an adviser to Mr Touadéra, told the AFP news agency that “the CAR signed a defence agreement in 2018 with the Russian Federation and not with Wagner”, adding that “Russia has sub-contracted with Wagner, if Russia no longer agrees with Wagner then it will send us a new contingent”. Any tensions between Mr Prigozhin and Mr Putin are “an internal matter in Russia”.

In Mali, meanwhile, a recent gamble by the ruling junta looks even riskier. On June 16th the military-led government told a 13,000 strong UN peacekeeping mission to leave “without delay”. Last August, nine months or so after Wagner arrived, French troops left after a nine-year deployment. The junta hoped that Russia would protect it from repercussions at the UN and that Wagner would help it fight the jihadists who have killed thousands over the past several years. Yet as the mutiny unfolded Sadio Camara, the junta's minister of defence, was “almost feverish” with anxiety, reported Jeune Afrique , a magazine based in Paris.

Since the mutiny, African elites may well be changing their opinion of Russia. Jędrzej Czerep of the Polish Institute of International Affairs notes that some of Africa's most influential cheerleaders for Russia have gone quiet in recent days. This reflects how support for Russia depends on it being seen as powerful enough to help its African clients achieve their own ends. “It will lose its charm as soon as it looks weak and incapable,” he argues. A long-anticipated deployment of Wagner forces to Burkina Faso, which like Mali is run by a military junta, is now surely less likely.

That points to an irony that will not be lost on many African observers. Russia's president pitches his country not only as a strong ally for African leaders but something of a model. Yet the very same group that his government has sent to help African leaders fight internal enemies has itself staged an uprising in Russia. That is hardly an advertisement for a regime selling coup protection to autocrats and juntas abroad. ■

O N JULY 1ST Def Leppard will perform at Wembley, the largest stadium in Britain, as the headline act for the first time (alongside Mötley Crüe). Like any aspiring hitmakers, the rock band started out playing much smaller crowds in much humbler venues. Def Leppard won attention in the late 1970s (pictured) after appearances at Crookes in Sheffield , Yorkshire, a private social club which is part of a network of venues up and down Britain usually referred to as working men's clubs.

For Def Leppard, deception was required, at least initially. The band would “turn up at a working men's club promising the MC we would play 'Tie a Yellow Ribbon',” the lead singer, Joe Elliott, has said. But instead of a set of soft-pop tunes familiar to the distracted drinkers, the group would play their own heavy-metal songs. There might be one pleased punter, Mr Elliott said, “but the rest of them just tolerated the noise.” Nevertheless, the band's breakthrough arrived when a journalist from Sounds magazine came to see them at Crookes, which resulted in a glowing double-page spread and then a major record deal.

The tale is not unusual: working men's clubs have played a huge and undersung role in the British music industry. Scores of bands in the new wave of British heavy metal between the mid-1970s and mid-1980s got their start in these venues—no matter how out of place they may have seemed and despite the risk of being “paid off” (ie, paid a fee and told not to return for the second set of the evening). Robb Weir of Tygers of Pan Tang says that they were dismissed in this way once. “Apparently it was all to do with the fact that we were too loud in the concert room for the bingo in the room adjacent to us. As we all know, bingo is sacrosanct on a Friday night at a working men's social club.”

The clubs' role as incubators of rock music might have surprised their founders. The first club was opened in Reddish, a locale south-east of Manchester, in 1857; Henry Solly founded the Working Men's Club and Institute Union ( CIU ) in 1862. “The Club Rooms in every locality will form the strongest counter-action to the allurements of the Public House,” he wrote. Solly hoped the clubs would offer uplifting education for their members. However, their exemption from pub licensing laws—taking advantage of a loophole intended to allow the gentlemen's clubs of Pall Mall to serve alcohol to the ruling classes—meant they became better known for supplying cheap beer after pubs had closed.

A century later, though, working men's clubs had come to represent something else in the imagination: comedians in crumpled tuxedos telling jokes about their mother-in-law to aled-up patrons. So central were working men's clubs to popular culture that everyone, no matter how famous, graced their stages. So synonymous were they with entertainment that a television variety show of the 1970s, “The Wheeltappers and Shunters Social Club”, was set in a fictional working men's club. The programme featured acts who played at the club's real counterparts, including comedians such as Bernard Manning and The Krankies, the magician Paul Daniels, and musicians such as The Dooleys and Brotherhood of Man.

By the late 1970s the CIU was the largest private members' organisation in the world, with more than 4,000 affiliated clubs. (Nowadays, according to the CIU website, the number is around 1,600.) For some bands, playing at the clubs was a choice rather than a necessity. The Fall, for example, made a virtue of appearing at them. “It toughened you up,” said the singer of the post-punk band, the late Mark E. Smith . “They'd be throwing glasses—proper glasses, like—and spitting at you. I see a lot of groups today, and they don't know they're born.”

After their heyday in the second half of the 20th century, the clubs began a rapid decline, one linked to the changing economy and the downturn of industry in the northern heartlands . In the 21st century, though, they are back at the heart of grassroots music. A number of the old clubs have been bought and turned into widely admired concert venues. Crookes continues to host regular music events. In Leeds the Brudenell Social Club attracts big names from the world of indie; down the road in Hebden Bridge, the Trades Club has become one of the most beloved music venues in the country. In east London, the Moth Club—the former home of a South African club for ex-servicemen called the Memorable Order of Tin Hats—is a regular stop for hip up-and-coming artists.

Solly would not recognise his vision in the Moth, the Brudenell or the Trades Club. Perhaps, though, he would approve of their mission: providing uplift at reasonable prices. ■

; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 15:51:37 GMT /content/67d9hm1aqespqsaob2t36nenb9ro4trd https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/06/27/how-china-is-using-folk-religion-to-woo-taiwan As Britons grow more unhappy with Brexit, what happens next?

P OLITICS IS routinely dominated by the short run: in-party scraps; looming by-elections. But quietly shifting and longer-term trends risk being neglected. One such is the rise of disillusion with Brexit. Polls from YouGov, Ipsos and NatCen Social Research all find that sizeable majorities of Britons now regret leaving the European Union. The latest numbers consistently show a margin of as much as 60-40% for those wishing Britain had remained in the EU , compared with the 52-48% vote to leave in June 2016.

Had all of those with an opinion on Brexit voted seven years ago, the result would probably have been even closer. Still, the numbers suggest a steady shift. What explains it? Several factors, according to NatCen's Sir John Curtice, who spoke at a recent conference of the UK in a Changing Europe think-tank. Demography is one: older people mostly backed leave while younger ones preferred remain, so the passage of time tilts against Brexit. Those who did not vote in 2016 now break strongly against leaving the EU . Remain supporters are almost all still convinced they were right. But the most significant change is that as many as 20% of those who backed leave now say they would support remain instead.

为什么？ The obvious answer is disappointment with the outcome. Voters' concerns have moved beyond Europe to focus on more short-term worries—the high cost of living, falling real wages, struggling public services and high immigration. Brexiteers like to argue that such problems were largely caused by covid-19 and the war in Ukraine. Yet Brexit has clearly made at least some of them worse. Britain was one of the last G7 economies to recover to its pre-covid level of output; growth remains nugatory; most economists reckon extra barriers to trade have had damaging economic effects; inflation and interest rates are higher than in most other European countries; net migration is running at its highest level ever.

Most of the specific promises made by the Vote Leave campaign in 2016 have proved illusory, too. This goes beyond the notorious red-bus pledge of £350m ($445m) extra a week for the NHS . The campaign claimed that trade with the EU would go on much as before, red tape would be swiftly shredded and big new free-trade deals with America and others would be simple to deliver. The broadest promise, that there would be no downside to Brexit but only considerable upside, looks empty. When Nigel Farage, the former leader of the UK Independence Party, admits (as he did in May) that “Brexit has failed” and Sir Jacob Rees-Mogg, a Tory Brexiteer, is laughed at for citing the benefits of Brexit, rising disillusion seems less surprising.

This does not mean that there is growing demand to rejoin the EU . Europe is falling down the list of voters' priorities and almost nobody wants to reopen such a bitterly divisive issue. Yet there is plenty of scope to soften the hard Brexit deal signed by Boris Johnson in December 2020. In February Rishi Sunak, the prime minister, won kudos for negotiating the Windsor framework. That resolved many practical problems over the border in the Irish Sea that was created by Mr Johnson's decision to take Great Britain out of the EU ’s single market and customs union but leave Northern Ireland in both. As the chances of a Labour government after the next election increase, so do hopes that it can exploit the better mood music to improve relations with the EU .

Sir Keir Starmer, Labour's leader, insists he will not rejoin the single market or customs union. David Lammy, shadow foreign secretary, suggests the EU would not agree anyway unless the Tories changed their stance. But he also told a recent meeting of the EU - UK forum, a talking-shop in Brussels, that better relations with the EU were his “number one priority”. Labour leaders have floated various ideas. These include more formal security and defence co-operation; a veterinary agreement to facilitate trade in food; full association with the EU ’s Horizon and Copernicus scientific-research programmes; a mobility deal to reduce visa hassles for travelling musicians and others; and an enhanced agreement on financial and other services.

Three more suggestions for how thicker relations with the EU might be added to Mr Johnson's notably thin trade and co-operation agreement ( TCA ) have appeared. In May the UK trade and business commission, co-convened by Hilary Benn, former Labour chairman of the House of Commons Brexit committee, came up with 114 ideas for mitigating the damage to trade. In April the House of Lords EU Committee published a report on how to improve ties in the political, diplomatic, climate-change and mobility fields. And in late June the Tony Blair Institute, a think-tank, put forward its own shopping list of proposals for closer relations with the EU .

The biggest obstacle lies in persuading the EU to agree to any such ideas. At the meeting of the EU - UK forum, Maros Sefcovic of the European Commission suggested that trade barriers were likely to get worse not better, and saw little hope for big changes during a five-year review of the TCA that is due in 2025-26. The commission thinks the review should be about implementing the 2021 deal, not expanding it. The EU likes the existing arrangement, as it helps goods exports but does little for services, Britain's strength. It is also wary of a non-member cherry-picking the benefits of its single market without signing up to associated obligations.

There are two political lessons to draw from Brexit disillusion. One: it is no longer possible for the Tories to persuade voters who backed them in 2019 not to switch to Labour for fear of losing the advantages of Brexit—for these are so difficult to discern. The other: whoever wins the next election, the trend will be towards closer relations with the EU , not moving further away. The process may take longer than anti-Brexiteers hope, and it will always be a mistake to take EU assent to future changes for granted. Yet Brussels and national capitals will surely feel under pressure to be nicer to Britain, especially if Labour wins. The eventual destination is still uncertain; but the direction of travel now looks settled. ■

W HEN WAGNER GROUP mercenaries, commanded by Yevgeny Prigozhin, advanced towards Moscow on June 24th, they met little resistance on the ground. But the rebels did come under attack from the Russian air force—and shot down a surprising number of their attackers. At least one plane and six helicopters were apparently downed. This was acostly event for Moscow , in losses of men and reputation as well as aircraft. What happened?

As with all assessments of military losses since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the only information available is shared or leaked on social media, and has to be treated with caution. Posters often try to pass off pictures from previous conflicts as new kills, and validation is difficult. However, some sources have proved reliable. Analysts at Oryx, a Dutch open-source intelligence research group, have as previously done great service in corralling the available information.

The air force's most significant loss was a four-engined Il-22M “Coot” Airborne Command Post. This is a modified Ilyushin Il-18 airliner, packed with communications and computing equipment to relay data and to allow officers on board to oversee and control operations below. It has a crew of ten, all of whom were reportedly lost when the plane was brought down. The helicopters lost included one Kamov Ka-52 “Hokum-B” attack helicopter and one Mil Mi-35 “Hind-E” assault helicopter, plus four Mil Mi-8 “Hip” transports. Three of the Mi-8s are said to be rare MTPR electronic-warfare variants, equipped to carry out jamming against radar and communications. “We regret that we were forced to strike at air assets, but these assets were dropping bombs and delivering missile strikes,” Mr Prigozhin said later.

There are no reports of Russian jets being shot down, though they apparently did bomb the Wagner forces, as dramatic dashcam footage showed. The attack helicopters are armed with rockets, guided anti-tank missiles and cannon. Although designated as transports, the Mi-8s are equipped with rocket pods and have often carried out attacks in Ukraine. Wagner columns driving along main roads should have presented easy targets for air strikes—like the more than 1,000 retreating Iraqi vehicles destroyed by American forces on the notorious 'Highway of Death' between Kuwait and Iraq in 1991. This smaller encounter also seems to have been one-sided, but in favour of those on the ground.

How come? America's Department of Defence notes that Wagner operates a wide range of Russian military equipment, including Sa-22 Pantsir mobile surface-to-air systems. The Pantsir is mounted on a truck and has a radar linked to twin 30mm automatic cannon, plus up to 12 surface-to-air missiles. Wagner also has portable, shoulder-fired anti-aircraft guided missiles. But no information is available yet on how the aircraft were shot down, or why an airborne command-and-control post was dangerously close to a combat zone. Friendly-fire incidents are not uncommon with Russian air defence.

Russian helicopters have taken significant losses in Ukraine and now tend to stay low to avoid surface-to-air missiles. The failure of Russian helicopters to stop, or even apparently to slow, the rapid Wagner advance, may be another sign that their effectiveness against modern anti-aircraft defences is limited.

According to Mr Prigozhin, Wagner's only casualties from the air attacks were two dead and “several” injured—although images show several destroyed vehicles. Janes, a group of military analysts, estimates that 29 personnel from Russian aerospace forces were killed in the aircraft that were brought down. These deaths may be more politically important than the losses of expensive equipment losses. Nobody mourns an aircraft, but a dead pilot is another matter. Mr Prigozhin's brief mutiny was not bloodless, and Russians may be unhappy to see more servicemen die with no attempt to bring their killers to justice. ■

叶夫根尼·普里戈任和他的瓦格纳雇佣兵团伙在俄罗斯发动的短暂叛变是有一定因果报应的。弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 23 年的统治所面临的最严峻挑战是他构建政权方式的直接结果，而且他的财富和权力都归功于总统的庇护。这赤裸裸地突显了普京权力体系日益弱点，使他比以往任何时候都更加脆弱。

普京治下的俄罗斯是一个奇特的混合体：一个近乎中世纪的宫廷坐落在一个现代官僚国家之上。在这种“临时政体”中，权力的定义不再是一个人的正式角色，而是与君主的亲近程度。普京青睐的是这一级别的真实货币，尽管其价值和分布每天都在变化。这个法庭采用古老的分而治之的策略进行管理。具有故意重叠责任和对立利益的敌对个人和机构相互竞争。就像监督角斗比赛的皇帝一样，普京与众不同，是决定每个人命运的仲裁者。

在政治上相对有效的东西，一旦移植到战场上就被证明是灾难性的。瓦格纳只是俄罗斯几支独立军队中从未成功纳入正规武装部队控制的一支，即使在一月份总参谋长瓦列里·格拉西莫夫被任命来管理战争之后也是如此。

这些军队都有自己的政治议程。例如，车臣领导人拉姆赞·卡德罗夫（Ramzan Kadyrov）急于声称他的部队对普京先生特别忠诚，尽管他设法让他们尽可能远离战斗，即使这意味着撤销格拉西莫夫将军的命令。普里戈任先生同样需要展示瓦格纳的价值，并且显然已承诺他将为普京先生确保巴赫穆特市的安全，该市是乌克兰一些最惨烈战斗的发生地，以便及时庆祝 5 月 9 日的胜利日。

普里戈任是一个充满激情和决心的人，他与俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古的不和可以追溯到2018年，当时军方袖手旁观，允许美军在叙利亚打击瓦格纳纵队。由于巴赫穆特显然无法及时被抓获，普里戈任先生加大了对绍伊古和格拉西莫夫先生的攻击力度，称他们是唯利是图的无能之人。

尽管普里戈任先生的谩骂程度异常高，但俄罗斯高层之间时不时会爆发此类公开争吵。在普京的体制中，君主的职责是在事态破坏稳定之前将其控制住。然而，尽管精英阶层的担忧日益加剧，普京既没有意识到危险，也没有及时采取行动。他既没有解决普里戈任先生的争议点，也没有解除他在俄罗斯战线中最有效的战斗部队之一的领导地位。

相反，普京半心半意地同意了绍伊古的更微妙的反制措施，即要求所有雇佣兵直接与国防部签署合同。这将剥夺瓦格纳的自主权，从而剥夺普里戈任先生最宝贵的财富。面对起义或阉割的选择，他叛变了。他并不寻求推翻这位俄罗斯领导人，而是迫切希望通过展示武力来说服他的赞助人转而反对绍伊古。

虽然这次行动失败了，但普里戈任先生可能使该政权的垮台变得更有可能、更迫在眉睫。普京最不为人所知的特征之一是他不愿意做出艰难的决定。当没有简单的选择时，他就会犹豫不决，并且常常很晚才做出决定。自入侵乌克兰以来，他所面临的一系列棘手困境有时似乎让他陷入瘫痪。虽然他未能在绍伊古-普里戈任之争蔓延之前处理好这件事就是最明显的例子，但还有更多例子，从如何动员下一波预备役人员到如何处理科技巨头 Yandex 的出售。

普京或许安然度过了这场危机，但他的实力比以前更加虚弱。他的统治在很大程度上依赖于三个支柱：他的个人权威和合法性；俄罗斯财政储备的深度和他花钱解决问题的能力；作为最后的保障，他对安全部队的控制。

他的合法性在这三个方面都受到损害。尽管民意调查显示支持率极高，但公众和精英阶层显然都存在不满。普里戈任先生和他的部下从顿河畔罗斯托夫撤退时受到掌声的景象，向顽固的民众表明了这一点，他们并不认为他们是普京先生声称的“叛徒”。

目前，俄罗斯的金融储备看似依然健康。然而，西方约 3000 亿美元的资金被冻结，而支付战争巨额成本的需要也限制了购买忠诚度的选择。

最后，安全部队再次被证明不太可靠。他们显然没有预见到叛变，然后基本上持中立态度，既不支持瓦格纳，也不反对瓦格纳。他们中的许多人已经厌倦了一位总司令，他似乎愿意看到数以万计的臣民以不明确的战略为名献出生命。

这一切并不意味着普京将立即失去权力。然而，这场危机将使他更无力应对下一场危机。他创造了一批无情的机会主义者精英，他们支持他不是出于信念，而是出于自身利益，他现在必须担心有一天，他们中有足够多的人得出结论，让他继续掌权的危险超过了反对他的风险。 ■
